metadata.titleEn: Temporally corrected long-term satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) dataset (1995-2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset provides global monthly satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) data during July 1995 to December 2018 with a spatial resolution of 0.05 degree. This dataset was generated based on the temporal correction, spatially downscaling and multi-sensor fusion procedures. Compared with the results from ground flux sites, the long-term trend of this SIF product has a much better performance than current widely-used SIF datasets. This dataset could be beneficial for the estimation of global terrestrial carbon fluxes and for the projection of future climates.

Using this dataset requires the citation of this paper (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.isprsjprs.2022.10.018). If you plan to use our data in a manuscript, you must inform us of your analysis and publication plans well in advance of submission of a paper, give us an opportunity to read and intellectually contribute to the manuscript, and, if appropriate, offer co-authorship. Contact: Songhan Wang (wangsonghan@njau.edu.cn) and Yongguang Zhang (yongguang_zhang@nju.edu.cn)
metadata.instructions:
Data format: netcdf. (Every .zip file contains the monthly SIF of a year)
Spatial extent: 90S-90N 180W-180E
Fill value: -9999
Scale factor: 0.001
Unit: mW m-2 nm-1 sr-1

literatureList.titleEn: Temporally corrected long-term satellite solar-induced fluorescence leads to improved estimation of global trends in vegetation photosynthesis during 1995–2018
literatureList.referenceEn: Wang, S., Zhang, Y., & Ju, W., et al. (2022). Temporally corrected long-term satellite solar-induced fluorescence leads to improved estimation of global trends in vegetation photosynthesis during 1995–2018. ISPRS Journal of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing, 194, 222-234.

background: Representing the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) assimilated by the terrestrial ecosystems, vegetation gross primary production (GPP) largely drives the inter-annual variations in atmospheric CO2 concentrations (Beer et al. 2010; Forkel et al. 2016) and acts as a key process for mitigating climate warming (Pachauri et al. 2014). Estimations from global carbon budget suggest that more than 30% of the anthropogenic CO2 emissions were fixed by terrestrial ecosystems during the previous century (Friedlingstein et al. 2019). Recent studies have suggested that there are significant increasing trends of global GPP driven by the combined effects from CO2 fertilization, climatic and other environmental drivers (Fernández-Martínez et al. 2019; Friedlingstein et al. 2019; Wang et al. 2020a). However, the global spatio-temporal trends of ecosystem GPP still have large uncertainties among various products (Zheng et al. 2020). Therefore, observation-based GPP estimations are needed to reduce the uncertainties of long-term trend in global GPP and also help to improve the future climate projections by assimilating these data into carbon cycle and Earth system models. Currently, the long-term trends of global ecosystem GPP still have large divergences (Anav et al. 2015; Cai et al. 2014; Li et al. 2019a, 2019b; Stocker et al. 2020; Zheng et al. 2020). For example, due to the differential consideration of environmental drivers on vegetation production, the long-term trends of global GPP vary from -0.07 to 0.89 PgC yr-1 among tens of process-based, light-use-efficiency (LUE) and machine learning models (Zheng et al. 2020). Meanwhile, most of current global GPP products exhibited a poor performance in reproducing the interannual variations of GPP (Keenan et al. 2012; Yuan et al. 2014). More importantly, most of current global GPP product were mostly estimated by LUE or process-based models, which depend on multiple key assumptions and parameters (Anav et al. 2015). These limitations highlight the need for better and direct estimations of global ecosystem GPP at a long-term period. The rapidly developed and widely used satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) data provide an unprecedented opportunity to more directly monitor the long-term variations of ecosystem GPP at the global scale (Frankenberg et al. 2011; Meroni et al. 2009; Mohammed et al. 2019). Directly link to the vegetation photosynthetic process (Porcar-Castell et al. 2014), SIF has been widely used as the proxy of ecosystem GPP at leaf, canopy and global scales (Guanter et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2017).
research objective: Here, based on the time series of SIF data at the Sahara Desert as the benchmark, we present a practical approach to correct the temporal inconsistency of different satellites (GOME, SCIAMACHY and GOME-2) far-red SIF data.
challenges: Though satellite SIF datasets have been widely used for plenty of climatic and ecological studies, a lack of consistent long-term satellite SIF data has hindered its use for long-term assessments due to their temporal inconsistency induced by sensor degradation.
methods: The temporally corrected SIF datasets were then spatially downscaled to a finer resolution of 0.05° with the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method. Then, the individual time series of SIF data from the three satellite sensors were fused together to generate a continuously long-term consistent global SIF dataset from July 1995 to December 2018 (termed as LT_SIFc*). We further validated and compared the spatial and temporal characteristics of LT_SIFc* with the ground-based long-term GPP observations from 15 flux sites, modelled global long-term GPP time series, and high-spatial resolution SIF from TROPOMI and OCO-2, respectively.
dataset: Finally, we generated a long-term temporally corrected SIF product (hereafter LT_SIFc*) from Jul 1995 to Dec 2018 with a high spatial resolution (0.05°).
findings: Our results show that the LT_SIFc* can capture the temporal trends and inter-annual variations for both site- and global-GPP, and also the global spatial distributions of SIF at the spatial resolution of 0.05° validated with TROPOMI SIF (R2 = 0.76, RMSE = 0.11 mW m-2 nm-1 sr-1). Our temporally corrected and spatially downscaled global long-term SIF product has the potential for the better estimations of global spatial – temporal variations in GPP, and also could be helpful for the improvement in the predictions of future land carbon storage and climate change.

Verification.Question: Does the method of spatial downscaling with the light-use-efficiency (LUE) approach effectively improve the resolution of satellite SIF data to 0.05°?
Is the lack of consistent long-term satellite SIF data a significant challenge for conducting long-term assessments of ecosystem GPP?

Disjunctive.Question: Which method is used for spatially downscaling SIF datasets, light-use-efficiency, machine learning models, or process-based approaches?
What challenge is more significant for using satellite SIF datasets, temporal inconsistency due to sensor degradation or spatial resolution limitations?
Disjunctive.Answer: Temporal inconsistency due to sensor degradation

Disjunctive.Question: Is the long-term SIF dataset validated against TROPOMI SIF, OCO-2 SIF, or ground-based GPP observations?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the challenges in maintaining consistency in long-term satellite SIF datasets?
Where can temporally corrected SIF datasets be validated for accuracy?
What data collection method is used to spatially downscale SIF datasets to a finer resolution?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that addresses the temporal inconsistency of satellite SIF data?
Example.Answer: A practical approach to correct temporal inconsistency of different satellites' far-red SIF data is presented, using the time series of SIF data at the Sahara Desert as a benchmark.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge when using satellite SIF datasets for long-term assessments?
Example.Answer: A lack of consistent long-term satellite SIF data hinders its use for long-term assessments due to temporal inconsistency induced by sensor degradation.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset production process that improves the resolution of global SIF data?
Example.Answer: The temporally corrected SIF datasets were spatially downscaled to a finer resolution of 0.05° using the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method, and individual time series from three satellite sensors were fused to generate a long-term consistent global SIF dataset.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the techniques used for correcting temporal inconsistencies in satellite SIF data?
Feature Specification.Answer: time series of SIF data at the Sahara Desert as the benchmark

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges faced in creating a consistent long-term satellite SIF dataset?
What are the attributes of the generated long-term temporally corrected SIF dataset?
Feature Specification.Answer: 0.05° spatial resolution, July 1995 to December 2018 coverage

Quantification.Question: What is the temporal resolution used in the data collection process for creating a long-term solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence dataset?
How many flux sites were used to validate the spatial and temporal characteristics of the global long-term SIF dataset?
What is the spatial resolution achieved after spatial downscaling during the data fusion process for the long-term SIF dataset?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of temporal correction in the context of long-term satellite data collection?
Definition.Answer: Temporal correction in long-term satellite data collection is crucial for ensuring consistency across datasets obtained from different satellite sensors. It addresses the temporal inconsistency issues caused by sensor degradation, allowing for a more reliable and continuous dataset over an extended period.

Definition.Question: How is spatial downscaling applied in the context of generating remote sensing datasets?
Definition.Answer: Spatial downscaling is applied to increase the resolution of remote sensing datasets, providing finer spatial detail. In this context, it involves using the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method to refine the spatial resolution of satellite data to 0.05°, enabling more precise analysis of spatial trends and variations.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods of spatial downscaling and sensor fusion in generating a dataset differ in terms of addressing temporal inconsistency in satellite data?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial downscaling method uses the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method to achieve finer resolution, while sensor fusion involves combining time series from multiple satellite sensors to create a continuous long-term dataset. Both methods address temporal inconsistency, but spatial downscaling focuses on resolution improvement, whereas sensor fusion ensures continuity and consistency over long periods.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the temporally corrected dataset and the original satellite SIF datasets compare in capturing global spatio-temporal trends of ecosystem GPP?
Comparison.Answer: The temporally corrected dataset offers improved consistency and alignment with ground-based observations, capturing temporal trends and inter-annual variations more accurately than the original satellite SIF datasets. It shows a strong correlation with other high-resolution SIF products like TROPOMI, indicating enhanced accuracy in depicting spatial distributions and GPP trends.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between using ground-based GPP observations and satellite SIF data as proxies for estimating global ecosystem GPP?
Comparison.Answer: Both ground-based GPP observations and satellite SIF data are used to estimate ecosystem GPP, providing insights into carbon assimilation processes. However, ground-based observations offer localized, precise data, while satellite SIF data provide broader, global coverage with the potential for long-term trend analysis. The satellite approach directly links to photosynthetic processes, offering a unique advantage for global estimations.

Interpretation.Question: How could spatial and temporal downscaling methods be applied to improve the resolution and consistency of datasets over extensive time periods?
Interpretation.Answer: The temporally corrected SIF datasets can be spatially downscaled to a finer resolution using the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method, allowing for the continuous integration of data from different time series and sensors.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential benefits of integrating multiple satellite sensors to create a consistent long-term dataset for monitoring global GPP trends?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating multiple satellite sensors can generate a long-term consistent global dataset that captures temporal trends and inter-annual variations. This improves the estimation of global spatial-temporal variations in GPP and aids in predicting future land carbon storage and climate change.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges lead to temporal inconsistency in satellite solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence (SIF) data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Temporal inconsistency in satellite SIF data is primarily caused by sensor degradation, which hinders its use for long-term assessments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for direct estimation of global ecosystem gross primary production (GPP) over long-term periods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Direct estimation of global ecosystem GPP is needed due to large uncertainties in spatio-temporal trends among various products and the limitations of current models, which depend on multiple key assumptions and parameters.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for using satellite SIF data as a proxy for ecosystem gross primary production (GPP)?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Satellite SIF data is used as a proxy for ecosystem GPP because it directly links to the vegetation photosynthetic process and provides an unprecedented opportunity to monitor long-term variations of ecosystem GPP at the global scale.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the spatial downscaling of temporally corrected SIF datasets influence the accuracy of global GPP trend assessments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Spatial downscaling of temporally corrected SIF datasets to a finer resolution of 0.05° enhances the accuracy of global GPP trend assessments by providing higher spatial resolution data that better captures the spatial distribution and inter-annual variations of GPP, validated against ground-based observations and other high-resolution datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact of using corrected and fused long-term SIF data on predictions of future land carbon storage and climate change?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using corrected and fused long-term SIF data improves predictions of future land carbon storage and climate change by providing more accurate estimations of global spatial-temporal variations in GPP, which are critical inputs for carbon cycle and Earth system models.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind generating a long-term temporally corrected SIF product with high spatial resolution from 1995 to 2018?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to provide a more consistent and reliable dataset that can better capture the temporal trends and inter-annual variations of global gross primary production (GPP), aiding in the reduction of uncertainties in global climate models and improving future climate projections.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address temporal inconsistencies in satellite SIF data when developing global datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing temporal inconsistencies is crucial to ensure the reliability and accuracy of long-term assessments, as sensor degradation and other inconsistencies can hinder the use of SIF data for studying long-term ecosystem dynamics, particularly in relation to global GPP trends.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of using satellite-derived SIF data as a direct proxy for monitoring global ecosystem GPP over an extended period?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits include providing a more direct link to the vegetation photosynthetic process, improving the estimations of global spatial-temporal variations in GPP, and enhancing the predictions of future land carbon storage and climate change.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the spatial resolution of SIF datasets be improved for more detailed global analyses?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The temporally corrected SIF datasets can be spatially downscaled to a finer resolution of 0.05° using the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method, allowing for more detailed global analyses.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What validation processes are used to ensure the accuracy of long-term SIF datasets with ground-based and other external data sources?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The long-term SIF datasets are validated by comparing their spatial and temporal characteristics with ground-based long-term GPP observations from 15 flux sites, modeled global long-term GPP time series, and high-spatial resolution SIF data from TROPOMI and OCO-2.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the correction of temporal inconsistencies in satellite SIF data due to sensor degradation?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a benchmark time series of SIF data, such as from the Sahara Desert, allows for practical approaches to correct temporal inconsistency across different satellite sensors like GOME, SCIAMACHY, and GOME-2.

Enablement.Question: How does spatial downscaling contribute to the creation of high-resolution SIF datasets for global climate studies?
Enablement.Answer: The spatial downscaling of temporally corrected SIF datasets to a finer resolution of 0.05° using the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method allows for the generation of high-resolution global SIF datasets that are essential for climate change and carbon cycle research.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for integrating SIF data from multiple satellite sensors into a consistent long-term global dataset?
Enablement.Answer: Integration of SIF data from multiple satellite sensors requires sensor degradation correction, spatial downscaling, and fusion of individual time series to ensure consistency over long-term periods, enabling better estimation of global spatial-temporal variations in GPP.

Expectation.Question: Why might the temporal inconsistency of different satellite data pose challenges for generating a long-term dataset?
Expectation.Answer: The temporal inconsistency is primarily induced by sensor degradation over time, which hinders the use of satellite SIF datasets for long-term assessments. A practical approach is needed to correct these inconsistencies to ensure the reliability of the data.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using temporally corrected and spatially downscaled SIF datasets for observing global ecosystem processes?
Expectation.Answer: Temporally corrected and spatially downscaled SIF datasets provide the potential for better estimations of global spatial-temporal variations in gross primary production (GPP), helping to improve predictions of future land carbon storage and climate change.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the challenge of spatially downscaling satellite SIF datasets to finer resolutions, and how might this impact the interpretation of global GPP trends?
Judgmental.Answer: Spatially downscaling satellite SIF datasets to finer resolutions, such as 0.05°, can significantly improve the granularity of data, allowing for more precise mapping of global GPP trends. However, this process requires careful methodological considerations, such as the use of light-use-efficiency methods, to ensure that the downscaled data maintains consistency and reliability with ground-based observations and other high-resolution datasets.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what role do you believe multi-sensor fusion plays in generating a consistent global SIF dataset, and what challenges might arise from integrating data from multiple sources?
Judgmental.Answer: Multi-sensor fusion is vital for generating a consistent global SIF dataset as it combines information from various satellite sensors, addressing gaps and inconsistencies in individual time series. Nonetheless, challenges may arise from differences in sensor characteristics, calibration standards, and temporal coverage, all of which require sophisticated data processing and validation methods to ensure a seamless integration and a reliable long-term dataset.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can maintain consistency over long time periods given potential sensor degradation issues.
Assertion.Answer: A practical approach to correct the temporal inconsistency induced by sensor degradation involves using time series data from a stable benchmark region like the Sahara Desert. This correction is then applied to different satellite data sources before integrating them to create a consistent long-term dataset.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used to enhance the spatial resolution of a dataset derived from multiple satellite sources.
Assertion.Answer: The spatial resolution of a dataset can be enhanced through spatial downscaling techniques, such as the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method, which allows data from multiple satellite sensors to be fused and downscaled to a finer resolution, such as 0.05°, for more accurate analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the techniques used to correct temporal inconsistencies in satellite SIF data and discuss their effectiveness.
Request/Directive.Answer: The time series of SIF data at the Sahara Desert was used as a benchmark to present a practical approach to correct the temporal inconsistency of different satellites (GOME, SCIAMACHY, and GOME-2) far-red SIF data. Satellite SIF datasets have temporal inconsistencies induced by sensor degradation, which pose a challenge for long-term assessments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used for spatial downscaling and fusion of satellite SIF data into a consistent global dataset.
Request/Directive.Answer: The temporally corrected SIF datasets were spatially downscaled to a finer resolution of 0.05° using the light-use-efficiency (LUE) method. The individual time series of SIF data from the three satellite sensors were fused together to generate a continuous long-term consistent global SIF dataset from July 1995 to December 2018.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify challenges in creating long-term satellite SIF datasets and suggest potential solutions based on the techniques discussed.
Request/Directive.Answer: A significant challenge is the lack of consistent long-term satellite SIF data due to temporal inconsistencies caused by sensor degradation. Solutions include using the Sahara Desert SIF time series as a benchmark for correction and employing spatial downscaling techniques combined with fusing data from multiple satellite sensors to create a consistent global dataset.
